webTitle: Revaluation of business rates delayed 'to protect Tory areas'

fields.standfirst: Minister says government has delayed revaluation until 2017 to protect businesses from 'volatility'
fields.body:
High street campaigners have accused the government of delaying a revaluation of business rates because it would hit Conservative heartlands before the election in 2015.

The comments came after Brandon Lewis, the local government minister responsible for high streets, on Tuesday repeatedly batted away suggestions from members of the Commons business, innovation and skills committee that the government should look at urgently updating the property tax to help small shopkeepers. He said the government had delayed plans for a 2015 revaluation of rates until 2017 to protect businesses from "volatility". Information from the Valuation Office Agency suggested London offices would be the big beneficiaries of a change, not struggling shopkeepers.

But Paul Turner Mitchell, a Rochdale shopkeeper who has used Freedom of Information requests to gather data on business rates, said: "It's a political decision. A lot of Conservative-held regions in the south would have seen their rateable value go up just months before a general election if the revaluation had gone through."

He questioned the veracity of the VOA data and said that London offices would actually have paid more as a result of a revaluation for 2015 while retailers outside the capital would be paying at least 20% less. "Lewis's maths don't add up. The VOA has completely undervalued how property prices in retail have deflated outside London."

A fellow high street campaigner Bill Grimsey told the committee: "The only beneficiaries from this delay are big retailers while small ones in the north of England are suffering." Research issued by his team of experts this week suggested Britain's four biggest supermarkets would save £1.3bn as a result of the two-year delay to a revaluation, while independent retailers' rents were kept artificially high.

Grimsey, the former Iceland boss who recently reported on the state of the high street, called on the government to carry out a complete review of the business rates system rather than relying on research being carried out by accountants Ernst & Young for the British Retail Consortium. He said the industry body was influenced by its "biggest paymaster", Tesco, and not best placed to look after the interests of independent retailers.

webTitle: Marks & Spencer stems decline in share of clothing sales

fields.standfirst: Figures leaked to trade journal show that M&S held its overall share of clothing market in 24 weeks to end of September
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer has stemmed the erosion of its share of the clothing market before reporting its half-year figures next week. The retailer, which is battling to improve sales of women's clothing in particular, after two years of declines, held its overall share of the UK clothing market flat in the 24 weeks to the end of September, according to figures leaked to trade journal Retail Week.

Disappointingly for chief executive Marc Bolland, who revamped his team amid pressure to revive the stores' ailing women's clothing ranges, its share of the women's clothing market has continued to fall back, but the decline of 0.2% over the 24 weeks was an improvement on the 0.5% slip in the previous period.

Next week M&S is expected to report a 1.5% fall in underlying sales of general merchandise – a category mainly made up of clothing – for the six months to the end of September. That would be on a par with the 1.6% slide reported in the three months to the end of June. Some analysts have downgraded their sales expectations amid unseasonably warm autumn weather and signs that M&S continued to lose market share despite new clothing designs and a star-studded "Leading Ladies" advertising campaign fronted by actress Helen Mirren.

The company launches its Christmas advertising campaign this weekend.

webTitle: Energy firms 'overcharge by £3.7bn a year'

fields.bodyText: Some of Britain's biggest energy companies have been accused of raising households bills for no reason and systematically overcharging customers by £3.7bn a year as they were grilled by MPs over their soaring prices and profits. They were taken to task by Stephen Fitzpatrick, the chief executive of small supplier Ovo Energy, who launched a stinging attack on his larger rivals for being "the best filibusters in the business" when it comes to revealing how they make their money. After British Gas, npower, SSE and Scottish Power announced inflation-busting increases in household bills, Fitzpatrick said he "cannot explain any of these price rises" as his company is buying gas for 7% less than it was two years ago. The four companies that have raised bills in recent weeks are under increasing pressure to justify their higher prices after figures from the regulator Ofgem showed that network costs have risen by just £15 since last year, wholesale costs by £10 and green costs by £10. During the hearing MPs criticised the companies' executives for accepting large bonuses while putting up prices year after year and failing in their duties to protect poor households who have to choose between heating and eating. John Robertson, a Labour MP, warned that thousands of people were dying of hypothermia because they could not afford to pay their bills. He dismissed the companies' claims that they do not disconnect customers by pointing out that those who fall into debt are moved on to prepayment meters which in effect force them to "self-disconnect". "The big reason is they die of hypothermia and they can't afford to keep the heating on. By the time you have gone to look for them [after 30 days of no energy] it's too late," he said. The four major companies that have raised prices blamed a combination of rising wholesale prices, green levies and network costs for their latest round of £100-plus increases, taking the average bill to £1,315 a year. They said they could cut prices per household by £40 to £60 instantly if the government removed a charge for the ECO – Energy Companies Obligation – scheme to help poorer households cut their energy usage, with E.ON calling it a "stealth poll tax" and SSE saying putting it on bills was "morally wrong". Tony Cocker, chief executive of E.ON, even called for a competition inquiry into the market to clear the energy firms of any allegations of profiteering once and for all. Cocker also said Labour's promise of a price freeze "at a stroke has increased the long-term cost of electricity and gas supply in this country". However, Ed Miliband, the Labour leader, dismissed the claims of the Big Six energy companies as excuses and said he would take action against those that are "overcharging people and taking advantage of a broken market" by freezing prices and breaking up the firms if he wins power in 2015. Fitzpatrick said he was "somewhat confused by looking at the explanations for the price rises over the past three or four weeks because we do not see really the same impact, especially in wholesale commodity prices. "We buy all of our power and gas on the wholesale market and … the most expensive price we have paid for wholesale gas in the last four years was in May 2011, for the following winter – that was 74p a therm. "Since then it has been below 72p a therm for this winter, last winter and next winter. We are buying gas for next winter at a current price of 69p a therm." He laid into RWE npower for being the "worst offender" in terms of offering some of the most expensive tariffs, and British Gas for its tactic of swiftly offering people much cheaper prices when they say they are about to switch supplier. He said the big companies could easily get round MPs' questions with "very complex, very clever, very confusing answers", adding: "You'll never get to the bottom of it." He added: "We are all trying to track were the money has gone, and you will never find it." Some of the big companies offer cheaper fixed-rate deals than Ovo and other small suppliers, but these are only taken up by a minority of savvy customers. Millions of British households are on the most expensive tariffs, which cost up to £150 more – or £3.7bn in total – than the prices that Ovo claims accurately reflect the costs of supplying energy with a 5% profit margin. Sitting next to representatives of E.ON, npower and SSE, Fitzpatrick said it was also "common practice among several of our competitors that they load the environmental and social obligation costs on to those customers that are less likely to leave. It looks to me like a lot of energy companies, a significant number of the Big Six, are charging the maximum price they feel they can get away with to the customers that they feel will not switch under any circumstances and then maintaining the illusion of competitive pricing with tariffs targeted towards a very small number of relatively well-engaged customers. "In the case of npower, which is the worst offender, historically and today the price differential is about 16%, which is about £200. That's more than the increase we have seen." Turning to his rivals' sales practices, Fitzpatrick complained that "one in five customers joining today are immediately leaving to go back to the previous supplier because of a win-back inducement that can be up to 15% off the bill". He said: "When a customer calls their supplier and says I'm going to leave, they say hold on a moment, we've just found out we can save you £160. British Gas seems to be the most active, with a dedicated win-back team whose sole job it is to call people up and there's a terrible mistake, we've been overcharging you all this time and now we can cut your bill. When this kind of behaviour is allowed to go unchallenged, this ex-monopoly advantage by the Big Six goes unchallenged by Ofgem, we'll never get effective competition." Andrew Wright, interim chief executive officer of Ofgem, said it was "absolutely right" that there should be a debate about its powers to regulate the industry and promised an annual competition review, but his evidence to MPs was cut short by a parliamentary vote in the Commons.

webTitle: Nasdaq hit by another computer glitch

fields.standfirst: The outage, which lasted an hour, forced the exchange to halt trading in derivative contracts linked to the Nasdaq 100 index
fields.body:
Nasdaq, the Wall Street stock exchange that specialises in technology shares, was hit by another computer glitch on Tuesday– the latest in a series of embarrassing malfunctions that have afflicted its trading platform. The outage, which lasted an hour, forced the company to halt trading in derivative contracts linked to the Nasdaq 100, the index of the most valuable companies listed on the exchange. Trading in shares was unaffected, the company said.

Tuesday's problems followed a high profile breakdown in August, which resulted in a three-hour outage. The company said on that occasion the the failure had resulted from a glitch in software that publishes the prices of stocks listed on the exchange. This was followed by a far shorter shutdown in September.

Those embarrassments followed Nasdaq's agreeing to pay a $10m (£6m) penalty to settle federal civil charges in May after regulators said its systems and decisions disrupted Facebook's flotation last year.

The exchange also agreed to refund $62m to investment firms that lost money because of the Facebook problems.

Some of the largest American companies, including Apple and Facebook, are listed on Nasdaq, while about 20% of the 500 largest companies traded on Wall Street – the so-called S&P 500 index – call Nasdaq their home.

webTitle: Post Office and Royal Mail staff to strike

fields.standfirst: Up to 4,000 workers in UK's main post offices will strike on Monday over issues of pay, branch closures and job cuts
fields.body:
Britain's postal system faces severe disruption next week when thousands of Post Office staff join Royal Mail workers in a co-ordinated strike.

Up to 4,000 workers in hundreds of the UK's main post offices will strike on Monday over issues of pay, branch closures and job cuts in the latest round of a long-running dispute.

For the first time since Post Office workers began this series of strikes they will be joined by Royal Mail workers, who are seeking agreements from the newly privatised service in a separate dispute.

Adding to the potential disruption they will be joined by up to 1,500 Post Office support staff, including cash-van drivers, striking against a pay freeze.

The Communication Workers' Union predicted the coordinated action would cause far greater disorder than any of the previous dozen strikes by its members at the 372 crown post offices, the network's large town-centre branches.

Dave Ward, CWU's deputy general secretary, said: "We are coordinating strike action across postal companies for 4 November to increase the impact of the action and try and focus the minds of company negotiators.

"The company is unfairly imposing pay freezes on both crown staff and now admin and supply chain workers, while senior managers have enjoyed significant bonus payments. These double standards cannot continue and we hope to make progress in talks this week."

Previous rounds of Post Office strikes caused widespread branch closures and long queues outside those premises which did open as managers struggled to provide a skeleton service.

Even if branches are kept open, customers will not be able to post parcels, and a lack of cash-van drivers could cause offices to run low on money, the CWU said.

The announcement came as shares in Royal Mail closed at £5.34, up more than 60% from their float price of £3.30, valuing the company at more than £5bn.

Last week it emerged that one of the company's biggest shareholders is a combative hedge fund – the Children's Investment fund, which has been branded a "locust" in Germany and which holds more than 5% of the company.

Monday's action will be the Post Office workers' 13th one-day strike since Easter Saturday over a pay freeze and over plans to close or franchise out 75 offices while cutting up to 1,500 jobs.

The industrial action by up to 115,000 Royal Mail and Parcelforce workers on the same day will be the first national strike since 2009. It will hit deliveries, collections and other facilities such as sorting, logistics and call centres, the CWU said.

The union said crown Post Offices workers had voted nine-to-one in favour of the strike; they had not had a pay rise since April 2011 while other Post Office members had received increases totalling 6.75% and top managers had enjoyed big paydays.

The Post Office said that most crown branches had opened on previous strike days and that its 11,500 smaller branches would not be affected.

But the union said the main branches handled 20% of customers and 40% of financial services sales, and that services such as currency exchange would not be available in many branches staying open.

The Post Office said it was investing in the crown branches and that plans to franchise out some of the offices would not cause closures or compulsory job losses.

A spokesperson for the Post Office said: "The union are calling for an above-inflation pay agreement when last year our overall performance was a loss of £116m. We must reverse this loss of public money.

"CWU have refused their members a fair and affordable pay offer of cash payments totalling up to £3,400 by April 2015.

"Strike action can only cost our people money, cause disruption to customers and threaten our plans to turn the business around and keep our branches on high streets and in city centres across the UK."

webTitle: Banks continue to count the cost of colossal PPI mis-selling

fields.bodyText: To many people, the real PPI scandal still being plagued daily by text messages claiming they are in line for a windfall. A colleague of mine regularly receives up to five a day. "Urgent, you are owed £3350 for the PPI you took out, time is running out to claim," says one. Earlier on, the figure was £2,351, the day before, £2,560. He has, of course, never taken out PPI. A bunch of opportunistic ambulance chasers? Almost certainly. But even the epidemic of text pestering and spurious promises made by the claims companies can't mask what was a colossal mis-selling exercise by the banks. It's now certain that the total bill will exceed £20bn – equal to more than £500 for every man and woman of working age in Britain. Lloyds alone has now made provisions totalling £8bn, with another £750m added on Tuesday. This comes as a surprise after the complaints figures from the Financial Conduct Authority, published a fortnight ago, appeared to show that the worst was over for PPI payouts. Lloyds admitted that four out of five complaints it received in the first half of 2013 were about PPI, but they were in total down by a third on the second half of 2012, and the trend was firmly down – yet provisions continue to surprise analysts. In the next 72 hours we will see the quarterly results from Barclays and RBS, and we will discover if Lloyds was simply an outlier – or that maybe even £20bn won't be enough to cover the mis-sale of the century.

fields.standfirst:
• Energy companies accused of 'unfair' profits
• Big six fail basic transparency test, say MPs
fields.body:
7.09pm GMT

Closing summary

We will have to wait another day to hear full evidence from Andrew Wright at Ofgem, who is asked to come back later. 

Quick summary: Energy bosses defended their price increases and argued for green levies to be moved off customers' bills and into general taxation.

Tony Cocker of E.ON said he had called on the prime minister to launch a competition investigation.

I fundamentally believe that this market is competitive but I acknowledge we are not trusted and therefore I believe we need to have a very thorough competition commission investigation.

Andrew Wright of Ofgem said the regulator had launched "the most significant reforms" since competition was introduced.

John Robertson for Labour accused the companies of failing to protect their most vulnerable customers.

There are thousands of people dying because of government policy... and the big reason is they die of hypothermia because they can't afford to put the heating on.

To just say you move them on to prepayment because they cannot afford to protect their bills, sorry, you need to do more to protect them.

That's all from me today. Thank you for following and join us tomorrow for more rolling news on the Guardian business blog.

Updated at 7.10pm GMT

MPs will no doubt try to get to the bottom of what is really happening to wholesale energy prices, and how they affect household bills.

As Rowena Mason, The Guardian's political correspondent, reports:

Some of Britain's big six energy companies have seen their wholesale electricity costs fall over the last three years while still putting up prices for millions of households.

The figures will put yet more pressure on the firms to explain why bills and UK profits have been going up, as they appear before a influential House of Commons committee of MPs.

Overnight India's central bank raised interest rates for a second consecutive month in an attempt to fight inflation and despite sluggish growth.

fields.bodyText: We will have to wait another day to hear full evidence from Andrew Wright at Ofgem, who is asked to come back later. Quick summary: Energy bosses defended their price increases and argued for green levies to be moved off customers' bills and into general taxation. Tony Cocker of E.ON said he had called on the prime minister to launch a competition investigation. I fundamentally believe that this market is competitive but I acknowledge we are not trusted and therefore I believe we need to have a very thorough competition commission investigation. Andrew Wright of Ofgem said the regulator had launched "the most significant reforms" since competition was introduced. John Robertson for Labour accused the companies of failing to protect their most vulnerable customers. There are thousands of people dying because of government policy... and the big reason is they die of hypothermia because they can't afford to put the heating on. To just say you move them on to prepayment because they cannot afford to protect their bills, sorry, you need to do more to protect them. That's all from me today. Thank you for following and join us tomorrow for more rolling news on the Guardian business blog. Over on the Spectator's Coffee House blog, Isabel Hardman sounds underwhelmed by MPs' performance in taking on the energy bosses: "the energy companies have hardly had the grilling they were expecting: more of a gentle warming." She writes that the person who has done the most to make the big six witnesses uncomfortable is one of the other witnesses: Stephen Fitzpatrick, the managing director of Ovo Energy. He took apart those sitting next to him in the Thatcher Room, saying that Ovo couldn’t see the prices on the wholesale market that would lead to the sort of rises that the Big Six have been announcing recently. John Rentoul at the Independent also thinks that the MPs failed to inflict "ritual cathartic humiliation". Normal people don’t have to sit through select committee meetings, but I suspect that most of us have an understanding of market economics that works at two levels. Level one is that prices seem to go up a lot, don’t seem to go down when world prices go down, and that the bosses of a lot of companies seem to get paid an awful lot, which doesn’t seem to go down if their companies do badly. But level two is that nationalising the energy industry would not make gas and electricity bills magically cheaper. Still waiting for MPs to return to the Thatcher room to wrap up this session on the 'big six' with Ofgem's chief executive. So time for a quick backgrounder: earlier this year the committee accused Ofgem of failing to improve transparency in the energy market. Ofgem hired BDO accountancy firm to advise on financial reporting of energy companies, but then failed to take up its recommendations, arguing they would put unnecessary burdens on the big six. MPs rejected this argument in their report on energy prices, profits and poverty: We believe that taken as a whole, the benefits of BDOs recommendations - in terms of improvements to transparency and comparability of the statements and associated improvements in consumer trust - significantly outweigh any burdens on the six largest vertically integrated energy companies. We recommend that Ofgem should require the six largest vertically integrated companies to implement BDO' recommendations 1 (publishing statements to the same year-end), 2 (independent auditor opinion on statements), and 4(reporting of trading function results). We also encourage Ofgem to consider requiring implementation of BDO's recommendations in full and to publish, in its response to this report, its analysis of the cost to energy companies of full implementation. With MPs calling Ofgem "a paper tiger", it is not only the big six energy bosses that are attempting to defend their reputations today. The division bell is ringing again. Short break while MPs go off to vote. Alan Whitehead is asking about the BDO recommendations (see 4.08 for background). Wright says Ofgem has committed to looking again at those recommendations and will be coming out with a call for evidence and "engaging with stakeholders". We have led the way in improving transparency in this market.. without the actions we took this debate would not be possible. This should be seen as Ofgem's defence, after the same group of MPs criticised the regulator for dismissing the BDO report, a series of recommendations to improve transparency. One MP thinks a different energy market model could work better: why not have "fierce competition" in generating electricity, but have co-operatively owned business model to supply consumers. Wright says there are many different models of running energy systems throughout the world. "It is the government's policy to have a competitive market in the supply of retail and gas." Sounding non specific (to my ears), Wright says the regulator has a range of powers to ensure the market is working properly. Andrew Wright says the regulator is introducing the "most significant reforms" since competition was introduced that will make a real difference to consumers and suppliers. Worth a quick reminder that earlier this year the committee criticised Ofgem for not doing enough to ensure companies were open and transparent. You can read the full report here. Now in the final session MPs are quizzing Andrew Wright, the interim chief executive officer of regulator Ofgem. He starts by promising an annual review of market competition starting next spring. And on that note, part two is over, with the feed cutting our abruptly... Ian Peters confirms to Labour MP Ian Lavery that British Gas made £1.08 bn pre tax profits last year. John Robertson (Lab) accuses the companies of not doing enough to protect people in fuel poverty. There are thousands of people dying because of government policy... and the big reason is they die of hypothermia because they can't afford to put the heating on. To just say you move them on to prepayment because they cannot afford to protect their bills, sorry you need to do more to protect them. The executives all say they will do more... John Robertson is asking about "excessive" charges for sending out letters and disconnecting customers. He says when indebted customers are moved onto prepayment metres, they are being "disconnected by the back door". Ian Peters of British Gas says it is a responsible way for these customers to repay debts. He claims British Gas is the only energy company checking to make sure these customers are not cut off. Martin Lawrence says EDF hasn't made its mind up yet on whether it plans to raise prices. Ramsay Dunning of Co-operative Energy, says the energy sector has a perception problem. It looks like an oligopoly. He doesn't think it is, but argues that potential new market entrants are deterred by lack of market transparency. I am not asking for the breakup of the big six, but we need to do something to change that appearance. He argues that power generation and retail supply of energy to households should be split. This "vertical integration" feeds the perception of an uncompetitive industry. Alan Whitehead, Labour, wants to know why 'big six' energy company price rises march in step. Ian Peters of British Gas says 2013 is an unusual year, partly because of the introduction of the eco-levy. Neil Clitheroe of Scottish Power takes up the eco levy tax argument, saying the UK is one of the few countries that puts the charge on bills. "If that separate people we could reference that point straight away and say that's what we pay." JR -This is emerging as the line-to-take for the energy companies today. Martin Lawrence of EDF chips in, asking for more stability and clarity about the future of the green levy. Now Ian Peters of British Gas argues that the eco levy should be shifted into general taxation, rather than put on customers' bills. Christopher Pincher (Conservative), citing research from the Institute of Public Policy Research, says that 1/3 of British Gas price hike could be avoided if they delivered on energy efficiency. Peters says he doesn't understand where that analysis comes from. Ian Peters of British Gas says 1% of the fall in customers' energy use is not related to energy efficiency measures, suggesting this could be related to changing habits. Clitheroe is saying energy efficiency measures are leading to reductions in consumption. But one MP want to know how much of that consumption drop is because people cannot afford to heat their homes. Clitheroe says that is difficult to answer. The last round of questions on the renewable obligation didn't elicit much substance from anyone. Now Christopher Pincher (Conservative) picks up the green levies again. Neil Clitheroe is setting out how Scottish Power accounts for its recent £98 cost increase: including a £33 rise in wholesale prices and a £20 increase in environmental and social costs. Questioned why the rise in wholesale prices is greater than their competitors, he refers to the spike in gas prices last winter. Back up and running again with the wholesale market price for gas under scrutiny. Ramsay Dunning of Co-op Energy, which recently put up prices by 4.5% for its 150,000 customers, explains why their costs are rising more slowly than for the rest. He says they do not bear the full amount of eco costs that the big six do, however neither does the Co-Op benefit from economies of scale. And he adds: We can sustain ourselves on lower levels of profitability Natalie Bennett, leader of the Green party, has given her reaction to today's committee meeting: It's excellent that senior executives are 'facing the music' before MPs today, but what we need on energy policy is not uncomfortable squirms but effective action. "MPs are right to ask why energy prices have gone up by 9% on average when wholesale gone up by 1.7% this year, but what we really need are answers as to how we can have affordable energy bills in future, warm comfortable homes and an energy industry that provides a range of jobs and economic opportunities for Britain. That means we need a serious focus on energy conservation, particularly home insulation, to end the scandal exposed today by the Children Society of the more than half of the 3 million children living in poverty who say their home is uncomfortably cold, and the 26% who say their home suffers from mould or damp. A quick recap for anyone just joining us: senior executives at nPower (RWE) and SSE have defended their price rise policy, claiming it was unavoidable because rises in the wholesale price of gas. E.ON refused to rule out a price rise. All three denied working in concert and insisted they ran transparent companies. Energy minnow Ovo Energy, which has 140,000 customers, pleaded for more competition and said it could cut customers' bills if it was in the position of RWE. A snap verdict: no MP has landed a killer blow, but they are clearly not buying the energy companies' arguments. The Thatcher room in Portcullis House, where energy bosses are meeting MPs, is still looking pretty empty. It seems appropriate this debate about energy prices - effectively a debate about the effectiveness of competition started by Margaret Thatcher - is happening here. The division bell is ringing and members are off to vote. Should be back in 10 minutes, says the committee chair. Ian Peters of British Gas defends the difference between his firm's 9.2% increase in wholesale costs, when Ofgem showed that wholesale prices were going up by much less. He says that this is comparing apples with bananas, because the Ofgem figures are forward-looking. Ramsay Dunning of Co-op Energy says his energy firm is run in a very different way from the big six. Now up is Neil Clitheroe of Scottish Power, who is defending his company's 8.6% price rise. He says it is "extremely difficult to make these decisions" and tells Owen his bonus has been flat for the past few years. Owen "You are comfortable taking bonuses when your customers are struggling?" Clitheroe says he is not comfortable with what is happening to his customers. Peters says that Sam Laidlaw, Centrica boss, is getting a bonus because the company is making profits by expanding overseas. Owen: "You don't lead by example. The rest of the country is struggling wage freezes." Ian Peters, managing director of British Gas, steps up for this question. He says executive remuneration is a bigger issue than just the energy issue and bonuses are set by an independent committee. "It is very transparent and the terms are put to our remuneration committee every year." Owen sounds unimpressed by this argument. Since 2008 the average British Gas bill has gone up by 38%, while the chief executive of Centrica - who is not here today - had a rise of 36%, up to £2.35m, he says. "That is the question I am asking, how do you justify that?" First up, Albert Owen (Lab): "How can you justify when people are struggling and inflation is at 2-2.5%, how can you justify these rises and give your executives huge pay rises? "Don't you think that the restraint that the British public is under should apply to your executives as well?" Owen says he is a customer for British Gas, but he might not be for much longer. And on that note, the first session is wrapping up.. next up Scottish Power, British Gas, EDF and Co-op Energy. Fitzpatrick calls on his competitors "to treat every customer fairly". He says if energy companies want to be trusted, you shouldn't be able to save 16% moving from one tariff from another, where profit margins are 5%. "Everytime they call up to complain, they get a deal dangled in front of them." Now it is Guy Johnson's turn to defend nPower's transparency record. He concedes that customers should have "fewer tariffs, clearer bills". William Morris of SSE defends his company's record on transparency and says they plan to act on recommendations from accountancy firm BDO to make improvements. The energy and climate change committee called on the firms to act on this report in a report earlier this year. Read the background on transparency recommendations here. Dan Byles, a Conservative MP, says he is none the wiser about energy companies' structure and profits. "Would you accept that your accounting and reporting practices fail the basic tests of transparency?" Tony Cocker is defending E.ON's profit margins and return on capital. In Germany, E.ON recently closed a gas-fired power station. Morris of SSE chips in and says they also have concerns about some of their gas-fired power stations in Germany. Phillip Lee says he is puzzled about why generation is not more profitable, when people cannot simply decide not to use gas and electricity. He adds" If governments go down the energy efficiency route, it is going to screw your business isn't it?" Fitzpatrick of Ovo Energy is picking up his theme of more competition. He says Ofgem have "almost entirely failed in our lifetime." His firm is four years old. The latest energy market review does almost nothing to address the monopoly position that the big six enjoy. If all the energy companies charged the same prices as Ovo, there would be a £3.7bn saving for consumers. Phillip Lee, a Conservative MP, wants to know how many of the firms employed public relations companies before coming in. "There is a suspicion that you are a chorus line acting in concert." Ian Lavery, a Labour MP, is on the attack about fuel poverty and profits. "How can these profits be fair when people cannot afford to pay for their energy?" William Morris of SSE insists that the industry's profit margins are lower than the supermarkets, but adds "I do accept the point it is still a big number." Tony Cocker of E.ON says he has written for to the prime minister calling for a competition inquiry. He says that he fundamentally believes the market is competitive, but acknowledges they are not trusted. "It would be really helpful to de-politicise this debate, get experts to look at it and sort it out once and for all." A question to Fitzpatrick of Ovo Energy: "If I was to give you half of RWE's business could you do it better and make it cheaper?" Fitzpatrick says he would be delighted to, saying that RWE /nPower is responsible for highest bills. We are all trying to track were the money has gone and you will never find it. These companies are the best filibusters in the business. But he rejects Robertson's idea that the energy companies should have their generation arms hived off from retail. He argues the biggest problem is lack of competition. "Effective competition is the only solution to lower bills." Will you promise not to cut elderly and disabled people off in the winter even if they do not pay their bills, Robertson asks. The energy bosses are saying nobody gets cut off. Robertson is still unhappy about the lack of transparency over big six profits. According to Ofgem, energy companies make 23% profit on generating electricity while their own figures suggest profits 17-23%, he says. Yet these profits are not taken into account by their retail arms, when companies raise consumers' bills. Why? How can shareholders get dividends on 20% energy generation profits, while consumers get 10% increases in their energy bills he asks. Guy Johnson of nPower says the firm has taken £170m in subsidies for renewable energy in the last few years, "vastly dwarfed by the £2.3bn we have invested". John Robertson (Labour) wants to know where these companies are paying taxes. Tony Cocker of E.On replies: I assume therefore that the German company pays German taxes and the British company pays British taxes. Robertson I would expect a CEO to know... Cocker We pay taxes here in the UK and we are proud to pay taxes in the UK... Robertson You are not trying hard enough... John Robertson for Labour gets to the heart of the matter: Do you understand that the people in this country do not trust you? How do you expect to get that trust back? William Morris (NPower) says 15 months ago he was one of those people. He is a newcomer to the energy industry. We have a profound problem on our hands. Albert Owen, Labour, is also asking about the eco levies, pointing out they were only introduced in April. "Many of my constituents don't have the luxury of those discounts because they don't have a dual-fuel bill," he adds. So why should they have to pay more? If the green levies are lifted will you pass on the saving to your customers, asks Pincher (Con) referring to David Cameron's pledge to roll back green levies. "Unquestionably yes," says Johnson of nPower. "Pound for pound, penny for penny, that should come straight off the customer's bill." Tony Cocker of E.ON is not giving a yes or no answer. Christopher Pincher, a Conservative member of the committee, is asking nPower's Guy Johnson why their eco levy costs are higher than their competitors. We will do absolutely everything in our interest to deliver them as efficiently as possible. Johnson says fuel poverty is profoundly worrying for him. "We don't want anybody to be in that situation." Back onto the eco levies, Guy Johnson of nPower says the scheme add up to £60 on the bill. Tony Cocker of E.ON, which has not yet raised its prices, says the firm has not yet decided if it will raise its prices. "We will hold our prices as long as we can." This doesn't impress the committee - one MP says "it means nothing ". Cocker blames the green levies, describing them as "a regressive poll tax". Barry Gardiner, a Labour member of the committee, is going after the companies on their price rises, and why despite different strategies they all put up their prices at the same time. William Morris of SSE counters "things are changing". He says the firm has made a loss of £21m. Tony Cocker claims E.ON has invested £7bn in the last five years. "There is some misinformation that investment has stalled in the last five years, that isn't what I am hearing." He goes on to claim they have invested 100% of what they have earned in the last 5 years. Stephen Fitzpatrick of Ovo Energy says in January 2012 they were the first energy company to announce a price cut. Although it is worth pointing out this cut was wiped out in the following April with a price rise of 5.8%... Guy Johnson of nPower is being quizzed about profits and whether UK profits are being fed back to the home company. nPower is owned by German utility RWE. He insists "there is no old fashioned transfer pricing going on", but acknowledges "an element of concern and suspicion.. that there are excess profits". Tony Cocker of E.ON denies the charge that companies are subsidising their retail business. He says his business is very transparent. Stephen Fitzpatrick continues his attack on the big six: "A significant number of the big six are charging the maximum they can get away with." Now up Stephen Fitzpatrick from energy minnow Ovo Energy, based in Bristol with 140,000 customers. I cannot explain any of these prices rises. They are not the prices we see in the liquid wholesale market. Like some of the committee members I have been somewhat confused looking at the explanations for some of the price rises. Morris of SSE is getting grilled over the breakdown of SSE's costs. The wholesale energy proportion of the bill is half the bill, another large proportion is transporting energy, the cost of social and environmental schemes account for 10% of bills and have gone up 13%. "We would like to see those costs off customer bills and coming out of taxation." He says he is paying the same proportion of his income on these levies as someone living in fuel poverty, which "clearly isn't morally defensible". William Morris of SSE says that OFGEM have revised their position and says company "regrets profoundly" having to put up prices. "None of us want prices to rise." First question is on prices, how can they be explained when Ofgem says wholesale prices have only risen by 1.7%? We are getting started... introductions from E.ON, SSE, NPower and Ovo Energy Some background reading: The BBC has put together this handy explainer on the Big Six The Guardian's energy editor Terry Macalister has set out 5 questions they must answer. Here is a full run down of the agenda. As my colleague Jill Treanor has pointed out, it's worth noting that only E.ON have bothered to put up their UK chief executive. Panel 1 at 2.30pm Tony Cocker, Chief Executive Officer, E.ON William Morris, Managing Director, SSE Guy Johnson, External Affairs Director, RWEnpower Stephen Fitzpatrick, Managing Director, Ovo Energy Panel 2 at 3.30pm Neil Clitheroe, Chief Executive Officer - Retail and Generation, ScottishPower Ian Peters, Managing Director - Energy, British Gas Martin Lawrence, Managing Director - Energy Sourcing and Customer Supply, EDF Energy Ramsay Dunning, Group General Manager, Co-operative Energy Panel 3 at 4.30pm Andrew Wright, Interim Chief Executive Officer, Ofgem Interest in the select committee hearing seems to be huge. Hi Jennifer Rankin taking over from Angela Monaghan. Now moving to one of the most keenly-anticipated event of the day. Energy bosses from the ‘big six’ energy companies, will shortly appear before the energy and climate change select committee. Energy chief executives are about as popular as bankers, so this should be a charged session. A quick recap: Sir Robert Smith, the Lib Dem chair of the committee, asked the energy companies to appear last week after a wave of price increase. NPower, British Gas, SSE and Scottish Power have all said they will increase electricity and gas prices by between 8% and 10.4% while Eon and EDF are expected to follow suit. The increases will take the cost of an average dual-fuel bill to more than £1,400 a year. You can follow the session starting at 2.30 here US consumer confidence dropped to 71.2 on the Conference Board's October index, from 80.2 in September (revised from 79.7). Economists had forecast a much more modest fall to 75. US markets have opened up: Dow Jones: +0.32% at 15,618.58 S&P 500: +0.27% at 1,766.90 Nasdaq: +0.05% at 3,384.39 Weak car sales were a drag in September, pushing overall retail sales down 0.1% on a monthly basis. It wasn't far off economists' prediction of flat sales. Excluding cars, retail sales actually rose by a 0.4%, and sales were 3.2% higher compared with September 2012. Economists said it was difficult to get too excited about the numbers because they related to the period before the US government shutdown. James Knightley of ING said: We have to remember that this was a pre-government shutdown figure and so its usefulness as a guide for Federal Reserve policy is limited. Europe's major indices are still higher. FTSE 100: +0.61% at 6,766.38 CAC 40: +0.5% at 4,272.78 DAX 30: +0.18% at 8,995.09 IBEX: +1.11% at 9,844.6 FTSE MIB: +1.75% at 19,158 London traders returned to their desks today after Britain's worst storm in a decade. While travel was severely disrupted and hundreds of thosands of homes lost power, economics editor Larry Elliot believes the economic impact will be limted. He argues: There are good reasons for expecting Britain's growth rate to slow down as 2013 draws to a close but the storm that has battered the south of England is not one of them. To be sure, a complete shutdown of the country would have an impact on national output, as was illustrated by the blizzards in December 2010. They had a material impact on gross domestic product in the fourth quarter of that year because the disruption was widespread and protracted. But that's not going to be the case this time. Firstly, the storm passed quickly and the Met Office gave plenty of warning that the bad weather was coming so people planned to work from home. Secondly, many workers were off anyway because of school half-term holidays. Thirdly, many of those who had an unexpected day off will have spent money in shops and restaurants. Finally, the fact that the bad weather came in October – the first month of the fourth quarter of 2013 – means there will be plenty of time to make up for lost output. There will have been some loss of output as a result of the bad weather, but at the most it will have shaved 0.1 points off GDP in the fourth quarter, and probably less than that. Katie Allen, the Guardian's economics reporter, tells how the biggest rise in UK mortgage approvals since February 2008 is "fanning fears" of a fresh housing market bubble: Mortgages approved by British lenders jumped to their highest level for more than five years in September, fanning fears the housing market was already heating up even before the latest government support kicked in. Banks, building societies and other lenders approved 66,735 mortgages in September, the biggest monthly total since February 2008, before the global financial crisis took hold. The figures, from the Bank of England, were just ahead of City forecasts for 66,000 and compared with an upwardly revised 63,396 in August. Mortgage approvals are seen by economists as a good early indicator of where the housing market is headed. They follow government data on Monday showing house prices rose in every English region in September and are likely to be seized on by those who argue that the government's Help to Buy scheme risks creating a new bubble. Read the full story here. Lenders from the International Monetary Fund, European Union, and European Central Bank - the so-called Troika - will pay a final visit to Dublin today. It follows the bailout which Ireland was forced into following the near collapse of its banking system at the height of the financial crisis. The country is hoping to become the first to exit the rescue programme. This from our Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald, in Dublin: Officials from the International Monetary Fund, the EU and the European Bank will make their 12th and final visit to the Irish capital today to review the Republic's economy as heads towards exiting the bail out. The so-called Troika will examine the progress Ireland is making towards driving down its national debt and moving to restoring economic sovereignty. Ireland will become the first country in the EU to leave the bail out programme. The Republic was forced to borrow 67.5bn euros (£57.4bn) after its biggest banks almost collapsed in November 2010. However, the state's debt-to-GDP ratio is still around 120% and Irish banks have yet to properly deal with the tens of thousands of its customers in mortgage arrears. Meanwhile, unemployment remains more than 14 per cent of the workforce. Our City Editor Jill Treanor is following the session live and tweeting here. Barry Tootell, former chief executive of the bank, has told MPs that the downgrade to junk status by Moody's in May was more severe than expected. He has also denied misleading the market about the state of the bank. See here for a great read on the Co-op fiasco. Turning to Spain, retail sales rose by 2.2% in September compared with the same month a year earlier. It followed a 4.8% drop in August according to official figures, and marked the first annual rise in more than three years. Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit, puts the rise into context on Twitter: UK mortgage approvals for house purchases (i.e. excluding remortgages) rose 5.3% to 66,735 in September, from 63,396 in August. It was the highest level since February 2008, before the global financial crisis intensified in September that year with the collapse of US investment bank Lehman Brothers. The Bank of England data will be taken as a further sign that Britain's housing market was warming up even before the second phase of the government's Help to Buy scheme was introduced earlier this month. However, mortgage approvals are still below pre-crisis levels, with monthly approvals averaging above 100,000 in 2006 and 2007. Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, had this to say on the Bank's data: The marked increase in mortgage approvals in September provides compelling evidence that housing market activity was already gaining appreciable momentum even before the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme came into being in early October. While the strength of house price rises in London is becoming an increasing concern and pushing up the overall national increase in house prices, we are currently a long way off from an overall housing market bubble emerging. Nevertheless, there is a mounting danger that house prices could really take off over the coming months, especially ifalready significantly improving housing market activity and rising buyer interest is lifted appreciably further by the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme It is therefore of vital importance that policymakers closely monitor the situation and are prepared to act quickly and decisively if signs of the housing market overheating become increasingly widespread and pronounced. The Bank of England also revealed that lending to non-financial companies rose by £720m in September., following a £3.7m fall in August. However, while lending to large companies increased by £1.1bn, loans to small and medium-sized enterprises fell by £383m. Adam Marshall, director of policy and external affairs at the British Chambers of Commerce, said more help was needed for SMEs: It’s good to see overall business lending rise, as this has an impact on business confidence. Yet these new figures show that while large firms have little difficulty tapping debt markets, SMEs – and particular young, fast-growing firms – continue to struggle to access growth capital. Both policy-makers and financial institutions need to do more to help fast-growing SMEs access finance. The British Business Bank has a huge role to play here, and should be enhanced with additional capital to help plug the gap. webTitle: Blockbuster admits failure in bid to rescue rental business

fields.standfirst: High-street DVD and game hire chain enters administration for second time in a year, with 2,000 jobs on the line
fields.body:
Blockbuster, the games and DVD rental chain, is set to enter administration for the second time this year in a move that will put 2,000 jobs at risk.

The business was one of the most high-profile casualties of a retail industry cull at the beginning of the year, when the HMV music stores and the Jessops camera outlets went to the wall. All three have undergone some form of revival since but Blockbuster's new owners admitted that a turnaround strategy had not worked as the DVD and games rental market moved online.

Gordon Brothers, the restructuring specialist that bought Blockbuster in March, said it expected to put the company into administration after suffering poor sales.

"Since the acquisition, we have worked extremely hard to reignite the Blockbuster brand, make our investment work and put the business on a viable footing," said Frank Morton, chief executive of Gordon Brothers Europe. "Despite our best efforts, we regret that we are now forced to make some redundancies and would like to thank any affected employees for their support during the last six months."

Blockbuster's new owners took on 264 stores, just over half the original chain, and promised to invest substantial sums in a revival plan. But it has been unable to secure a licensing deal with Blockbuster's parent company in the US to launch an online business.

More than 30 jobs at Blockbuster's UK head office will go immediately. The stores will continue to trade but about 2,000 shop jobs are at risk if a buyer cannot be found.Industry experts said Blockbuster's difficulties were the result of a change in the way people were buying and renting films and games rather than the economic downturn or problems with the business rates system.

Neil Saunders, managing director of retail consultancy Conlumino, said: "This is a business model that is no longer relevant." He said renting videos from a shop was rapidly being superseded by services such as Netflix or Lovefilm, which allow people to rent DVDs via post or stream films or games over the internet, as well as video-on-demand services offered through set-top boxes.

"The fundamental truth is Blockbuster is not needed and it's as logical as trying to open a chain of blacksmiths," he said.

The Blockbuster announcement came as MPs discussed on Tuesday whether changes to business rates were needed to help retailers.

Bill Grimsey, a retail campaigner and former Iceland boss, told the Commons business innovation and skills committee that the government should urgently review the way rates were calculated and scrap a decision to delay a revaluation of rates by two years to 2017.

He said: "The only beneficiaries from this delay are big retailers while small ones in the north of England are suffering."

Research issued by his team suggested Britain's four biggest supermarkets would save £1.3bn as a result of the delay but independent retailers' rents would remain artificially high.

Speaking after the committee hearing, Paul Turner Mitchell, a member of Grimsey's team, accused the government of delaying the change to business rates until after the 2015 election for political reasons because it would result in higher rates in Conservative heartlands in the south of England.

But Brandon Lewis, the minister responsible for high streets, batted away suggestions from members of the committee that the government should bring forward a revaluation of rates or undertake research into how the tax could be made more fair. He said the government had delayed plans for a 2015 revaluation of rates until 2017 to protect businesses from "volatility".

webTitle: HS2 figures threaten to derail DfT's business strategy

fields.bodyText: It was doubtless no accident that the transport secretary, Patrick McLoughlin, dispatched himself to the far end of the future HS2 line on Tuesday, rather than fronting up the vaunted new strategic case in London. It was left to civil servants to put a bright sheen on the remaining unleaked news: that the benefit-cost ratio for the £42.6bn high-speed rail scheme had dropped once again, to give £2.30 of benefit for every pound spent. The economists in the Department for Transport (DfT) have little choice but to continue applying lipstick to the pig, despite their caveats that no number can capture the unquantifiable, yet glorious benefits of HS2. The DfT makes awkward attempts to disown the methodology ("we know people work on trains"), supply more favourable future projections or appeal to common sense. But the original economic case presented for HS2 was comprehensively skewered by critics; to now move the goalposts, badger-style, would simply leave opponents claiming that the government was massaging the figures. So McLoughlin headed for Manchester, whose leaders have no doubt of the value of HS2 to them and have no truck with Ed Balls' opportunism in decrying "blank cheques". McLoughlin talked of capacity, jobs, space for commuter trains, the pain of alternatives: all compelling arguments for what he referred to as the "new north-south railway". But it's a measure of how unfortunately the case was originally made that, despite all the evidence that passengers put a high value on quicker journeys on any transport route, HS2's supporters rarely now mention the dread words "high speed".

webTitle: Tata Steel cuts 500 jobs, blaming industry slump and green levies

fields.bodyText: Tata Steel is cutting almost 500 jobs in Scunthorpe, Cumbria and Teeside, blaming a slump in demand across the European construction industry and the cost of green levies. Announcing the cuts, the company and its biggest union called on the government to do more to support the steel sector by helping with exports and encouraging use of UK steel in building projects. About 340 jobs will go in Scunthorpe, Lincolnshire, where Tata employs 4,000 workers. Almost a third of the 300 workers at Workington in Cumbria will lose their jobs and 40 jobs will go at Teesside, where Indian-owned Tata, which owns what was once British Steel, employs 1,500 people. The cuts come less than a year after 900 steel job losses, mainly in Port Talbot, Wales. Tata said then that the cuts were part of a plan to cope with terrible market conditions. Karl-Ulrich Köhler, Tata Steel's European chief executive, said: "European steel demand this year is expected to be only two-thirds of pre-crisis levels after falls in the last two years. On top of the challenging economic conditions, rules covering energy and the environment in Europe and the UK threaten to impose huge additional costs." The financial crisis exacerbated overproduction in the European steel industry. China's rapidly expanding capacity has also pushed up the price of iron ore, the sector's main raw material, while putting downward pressure on the price of steel. Eurofer, which represents the steel industry, forecasts that steel consumption will fall 4.5% this year in Europe with only 0.5% growth expected in 2014. Europe has emerged from its long recession but growth is still sluggish and manufacturing is picking up in the UK, albeit from a low base. Tata said steel is one of the last industries to benefit from economic recovery because customers can use stockpiles left over from the boom years before buying more. Tata and the Community trade union, which represents most iron and steel workers, called on the government to do more to support the industry. Michael Leahy, Community's general secretary, said: "The business has been dealing with a downturn in some of its markets for the past five years. Nevertheless, today's news once again reflects the fragile state of our economy and the lack of any real impetus by government to support our manufacturing base." The union called on the government to come up with a proper strategy to support UK industry, including giving companies incentives to use UK steel instead of cheap imports for big infrastructure and building projects. However, the Unite union accused Tata of trying to "sack its way out of a downturn". Its national officer Paul Reuter said: "We are urging the leadership of Tata Steel in the UK to look at what steps are needed to grow the company rather than slashing jobs."

webTitle: FTSE 100 hits new five month high but Tullow Oil slides after dry well

fields.standfirst: Investors push shares higher ahead of US Federal Reserve meeting
fields.body:
It has been a bad couple of days for Tullow Oil.

On Monday the explorer said it had temporarily suspended drilling operations in northern Kenya following demonstrations by local communities regarding concerns around employment in Turkana county.

Now OMV, the Austrian operator of a discovery in the Norwegian Arctic where Tullow has a 20% stake, has announced it drilled a dry well which will now be plugged and abandoned. The Wisting Alternative well was near a previous large find made last month and thought to hold up to 164m barrels of oil, but the latest development takes the shine off some of the optimism. Angus McCoss, Tullow's exploration director, said:

[This] was a high risk wildcat well which had provided important information about the regional geology in the Barents Sea. The material Wisting Central oil field, discovered in the same licence in September this year, will now be prioritised for appraisal in 2014.

Tullow' shares fell 21p to 936p. Richard Griffith at Oriel Securities said:

We had valued Wisting Alternative at 8p a share risked. Wisting Central is included in our risked net asset value at 10p a share. After a poor run Tullow's shares now trade at a 15% discount to our risked net asset value of 1123p a share. Still ahead of the peer group average discount of around 30%, but falling back towards the pack.

Still with oil, there was a brighter picture from BP. The company was the biggest riser in the FTSE 100, up 25.4p to 477.5p after it raised its third quarter dividend by 5.6% and said it would sell $10bn worth of assets over the next two years and return most of the proceeds to shareholders.

The company has already disposed of $38bn worth of assets to pay for the Gulf of Mexico spill, and this helped push net profit down from $5.017bn a year ago to $3.692bn. But this was higher than consensus forecasts of around $3.17bn.

Royal Dutch Shell A shares were also better, up 31.5p at 2168.5p, following the BP news.

But Lloyds Banking Group lost 1.61p to 78.01p after it put aside another £750m as a charge for the mis-selling of payment protection insurance, making a total of £8bn so far. Disappointing figures from UBS and Deutsche Bank also hit the sector, with Royal Bank of Scotland down 3.7p at 364.8p.

Helped by BP, the FTSE 100 finished up 48.91 points at 6774.73, a new five month high, while on Wall Street the S&P 500 hit a new record ahead of the two day US Federal Reserve meeting which ends on Wednesday. The central bank is widely expected to keep its $85bn a month bond buying programme intact for the rest of the year, but any comments on when it might begin to ease off QE will be closely watched.

Sentiment was also helped by the Peoples Bank of China injecting liquidity and easing fears of a credit crunch. Brenda Kelly, senior market strategist at IG, said:

The calm following yesterday's storm in the UK has seen the return of traders and indeed risk appetite, helping to push the FTSE 100 to highs last seen in May. The bullish sentiment, aided and abetted by poor US data, indicates that traders are kicking any notion that the US Federal Reserve will taper into the long grass for now.

Elsewhere Fresnillo fell 23p to £10.19 after its majority owner, Mexican mining company Penoles, said late on Monday that it third quarter profits fell nearly 25% from the same period a year ago.

ITV dipped 0.5p to 191.4p after Berenberg moved its recommendation from hold to sell with a 155p target, saying:

Our view on ITV is shaped by the conflict between its near and medium/long-term performance. While the third quarter has seen better-than- expected advertising growth, in the medium-to-long term we believe that ITV has poor online positioning and that this could be a driver of revenue downgrades over time.

Among the mid-caps, Man added 2p to 91p on renewed talk that a bidder - perhaps Bank of New York Mellon, perhaps Bank of America - could be interested in the hedge fund group. Traders mentioned a possible price of some 150p a share.

Housebuilders were in demand after Liberum Capital issued a positive note on the sector and raised its recommendation on Bovis Homes, 30.5p higher at 790p, and Redrow, up 9.1p at 263.9p. Liberum analyst Charlie Campbell said:

We are more positive because we anticipate strong trading updates through November's mini-reporting season. But we also see house price inflation continuing without getting out of hand, and rate rise fears abating. The combination of subdued land prices and government support also make this cycle better than the last....But there are enough checks and balances to ensure that price rises do not get out of hand (subdued real incomes, more rigorous mortgage market supervision and credit checking).
These positive factors should allow the sector's re-rating to continue.

Liberum also raised its price target on Persimmon, up 31p to £12.55, from £12.45 to £12.61.

webTitle: New York attorney general investigates Barneys and Macy's racism claims

fields.standfirst: As customers accuse the major stores of racially-fuelled incrimination, Jay Z's marketing deal with Barneys under scrutiny
fields.body:
New York’s attorney general is investigating allegations of racism at Macy’s and Barneys, two of New York’s most famous department stores. The growing controversy has dragged in rap mogul Jay Z and already triggered several lawsuits.

Eric Schneiderman’s office has asked the two department stores to provide by Friday information on their policies after several customers have accused them of discriminating against them on the basis of race. Schneiderman’s office said it had received similar complaints.

“Attorney general Schneiderman is committed to ensuring that all New York residents are afforded equal protection under the law,” Kristen Clarke, who heads the attorney general’s civil rights bureau, wrote to Barneys CEO Mark Lee and Macy’s chief stores officer Peter Sachse. “The alleged repeated behavior of your employees raises troubling questions about your company’s commitment to that ideal,” Clarke wrote.

The letters comes as Lee is set to meet with civil rights activist the Reverand Al Sharpton on Tuesday in an attempt to tackle the scandal. Jay Z – who has a marketing deal with Barneys – has also been dragged into the controversy. Jay Z said he has been “demonized” for not speaking out before all the details are clear.

Last week Barneys and the New York police department were served with a lawsuit brought by Trayon Christian, a 19-year-old college student from Queens. Christian was arrested at the luxury department store in April after buying a $350 Salvatore Ferragamo belt.

After the purchase, Christian was stopped by undercover officers who were allegedly called in by a Barneys sales clerk who believed the transaction was fraudulent. According to the lawsuit filed in Manhattan supreme court, the student was asked “how a young black man such as himself could afford to purchase such an expensive belt”.

Police allegedly accused Christian of using a fake ID when he produced the credit card and receipt for belt. He was handcuffed and taken to a local precinct.

Kayla Phillips, a 21-year-old nursing student from Brooklyn, has filed a $5m suit against the city and another against Barneys after she was detained shortly after buying a $2,500 Céline bag at the store on 28 February.

webTitle: Co-op Bank's former chief accused over £1.5bn capital shortfall

fields.bodyText: The former boss of the Co-operative Bank has been accused by a committee of MPs of running the business with such a tight capital position that a "puff of wind" could have blown it over. In an appearance at the Treasury select committee , Barry Tootell was repeatedly asked about the bank's assertions that it was in a strong position at the end of 2012, at a time when regulators were discussing its need for additional capital in the future. He insisted the capital buffer was adequate under the rules in place at the time. The Co-operative Group is ceding control of the bank amid pressure from hedge funds as the supermarket, grocery and funeral homes business races to plug a £1.5bn capital shortfall. Tootell, who insisted that the bank's capital position had been strong, was also accused of being affected by "corporate amnesia" at the Co-op Bank and "sliding away" from answers. Andrew Tyrie, chairman of the Treasury select committee, told Tootell that the bank's capital position was such that a "puff of wind could blow you over", and accused him of "sailing close to the wind" with his assertion that the bank had a strong capital position at the end of 2012. Tootell denied this. The MPs were taking evidence from Tootell, who quit after the bank was downgraded to junk in May, as part of their investigation into the failure of the mutually-owned bank to buy 632 branches from Lloyds Banking Group in a deal codenamed Project Verde. He Tootell quit after Moody's downgraded the bank more severely than he had expected, although he told MPs he had indicated his intention to go five months earlier. As finance director at the time when Co-op Bank merged with the Britannia Building Society, which is being blamed in part for the losses at the Co-op, Tootell told MPs he took responsibility for the analysis of the former building society's accounts and refused to blame an analysis by accounting firm KPMG. He said the regulators had scrutinised Britannia three months before the deal with the Co-op and concluded the building society needed up to £40m more in capital. The Co-op had conducted its own analysis and concluded there was a further £700m of potential "fair value" losses by Britannia. "This was never, ever discussed as a rescue," Tootell said when asked if the Co-op had been helping Britannia. He was appointed temporary chief executive in June 2011 after the resignation of Neville Richardson, the former Britannia boss who had been promoted to run the enlarged organisation. Tootell said the Co-op had pulled out of the takeover of the Lloyds branches in April on his recommendation, but he acknowledged that there not been "unanimous approval at all times" by Co-op group executives. Tootell set out two reasons for the £1.5bn capital shortfall – the bill for compensating customers for payment protection insurance (PPI) and the losses in its non-core lending, largely stemming from the Britannia acquisition in 2009. The scale of the capital shortfall did not emerge until June, after the Bank of England revealed that Co-op needed to find £1.5bn of extra capital after it had conducted an industry-wide analysis. Tootell said the Co-op had established that its capital position was becoming tighter in November 2012 while it was still in discussions about buying the Lloyds branches. But he felt the bank had a plan – codenamed Pennine – to rectify the position by selling its insurance business and cutting back on leverage. Evidence from the former Co-op bank chairman, the Rev Paul Flowers, has been delayed until next week.

webTitle: Rabobank boss quits over £662m Libor rigging fine

fields.standfirst: Piet Moerland to step aside earlier than planned as regulators penalise firm for 'one of the worst cases' in the scandal
fields.body:
The Libor rigging scandal was reignited on Tuesday when the boss of Rabobank quit after the Dutch bank was fined €774m (£662m) for manipulating the benchmark interest rate.

The fine, the second largest for Libor rigging after the £940m paid by Swiss bank UBS, was the fifth levied by regulators on both sides of the Atlantic in their attempt to crackdown on the manipulation of the key interest rate.

It comes as a new investigation begins into similar allegations of manipulation in the £3tn-a-day currency markets. UBS and Deutsche Bank became the latest to admit they were co-operating with investigations into currency benchmarks, as the US justice department acknowledged for the first time it was involved.

As Piet Moerland, the Rabobank chairman, announced he would step aside earlier than planned, regulators said some of the bank's traders had colluded with rivals at other financial firms to move rates to make a profit in one of the worst such cases they had investigated. About 30 individuals were involved, according to the mutually-owned bank – which was set up in 1898 to fund Dutch farmers and until now had escaped the financial crisis virtually unscathed and without needing the taxpayer bailouts handed to rivals.

There were 500 instances of attempted Libor manipulation, directly or indirectly involving at least nine managers. One manager facilitated a culture in Rabobank's offices in New York, London, Utrecht, Tokyo, Hong Kong and Singapore where attempted manipulation appeared to be accepted or even endorsed by the bank, regulators said.

Rabobank has also entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the US department of justice.

The regulators unleashed the customary cache of emails containing colourful language used by traders. One manager said to a trader that he was "fast turning into [that trader's] bitch!!!!". Another was offered "546 beers" for changing rates. "Don't worry mate – there's bigger crooks in the market than us guys!" one submitter wrote.

Moerland, who had been with the bank – which prides itself on its integrity and its roots in the agricultural business – for 30 years, said he was shocked by the practices uncovered. The bank did not lose its AAA rating until 2011.

"I sincerely regret that a number of Rabobank employees acted in an inappropriate manner. This should never have taken place at Rabobank," said Moerland. "The conduct of these individuals, and the language of some of the individuals' communications, has shocked me. Rabobank fully understands the sense of indignation that this will cause both within our organisation and more broadly."

The US regulator, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, said Rabobank employees had been making submissions to Libor that they saw at the time as "ridiculous", "obseenly [sic] high" and "silly low".

Libor – set in a number of currencies by special "submitters" at so-called panel banks – is supposed to be the price that banks would charge each other to borrow in the markets and is used to price about £300tn of contracts around the world. But Rabobank sat its submitters next to its traders and in some cases traders assumed the role of submitter. One of its US dollar traders was known as the "Ambassador" or "Ambass" while one of its submitters was referred to as "madame cadburry", according to documents released by the regulators.

The Financial Conduct Authority – which is levying £105m of the total fine – said the bank had no regard to the integrity of the market. Tracey McDermott, the FCA's director of enforcement and financial crime, said: "Rabobank's misconduct is among the most serious we have identified on Libor. Traders and submitters treated Libor submissions as a potential way to make money, with no regard for the integrity of the market. This is unacceptable."

The fine is largely related to yen Libor and, to a lesser extent, dollars and sterling.

None of the individuals were identified by the FCA although some were referred to by job titles by the US regulators. The FCA, along with other regulators, has fined Swiss bank UBS, RBS and Icap, as well as Barclays, the first bank to be fined, in June 2012.

In June, Moerland said he would retire from the bank next year. He is replaced by Rinus Minderhoud, a member of the supervisory board since 2002.

Moerland acknowledged that Rabobank had not appreciated the risk involved in setting Libor and its euro equivalent, Euribor. "We have taken severe disciplinary measures against employees directly involved in or otherwise responsible for the unacceptable conduct," he added. Some had already left and five been fired with €4.2m of bonuses being withheld.

SAC fraud

SAC Capital is to plead guilty to securities fraud as part of a landmark settlement over insider trading at the hedge fund, according to the Wall Street Journal.

The Connecticut-based company, which is run by the billionaire investor Steven Cohen, has been under investigation for seven years.

The paper said the exact timing of any agreement had not yet been agreed but a deal could be unveiled by the end of this week.

It comes as the US authorities are trying to finalise the details of a $13bn (£8bn) agreement with JP Morgan over the sale of toxic mortgage bonds. That agreement was expected last week, but talks appear to have stalled.

webTitle: Record labels win ISP blocks on 21 filesharing sites

fields.standfirst: Court order served to UK's six biggest ISPs covers nine BitTorrent sites and 12 aggregator sites including mp3skull
fields.body:
Music industry trade body the BPI has forced the UK's biggest internet service providers, including BSkyB, BT and Virgin Media, to block the public accessing 21 popular filesharing websites.

The UK's six biggest ISPs - BSkyB, BT, Everything Everywhere, TalkTalk, Virgin Media and O2-owner Telefonica - have received high court papers ordering them to block the websites from Wednesday.

The high court order to block the websites marks an escalation in the battle against piracy by the music industry, raising the number of infringing websites blocked significantly to a total of 25 including Pirate Bay.

Websites targeted include nine BitTorrent sites, and 12 music "aggregator" websites, such as mp3skull.

The BPI said it was forced to seek a high court order after the infringing websites "declined to co-operate in any meaningful way".

"We asked the sites to stop infringing copyright, but unfortunately they did not and we were left with little choice but to apply to the court," said Geoff Taylor, chief executive of the BPI. "The judge considered the evidence and declared that ISPs should not serve access to them."

Taylor said that previous high court orders to block four BitTorrent websites allegedly engaged in online copyright infringement had resulted in a "significant reduction" in their use by UK internet users.

"Music companies are working hard to build a thriving digital music sector in the UK, offering fans great convenience, choice and value, but these efforts are undermined by illegal sites which rip off artists and contribute nothing to Britain's vibrant music scene," he said.

Gareth Mead, a spokesman for Virgin Media, said: "As a responsible ISP we obey court orders addressed to the company."
