webTitle: Wall Street higher ahead of US Federal Reserve statement

fields.standfirst: Investors believe Fed will keep its bond buying programme after mixed data
fields.body:
As the US Federal Reserve starts its two day meeting, with a QE decision and statement due on Wednesday, a spate of data has done little to suggest the central bank will stop its $85bn a month bond buying programme in the immediate future.

The figures do not show the effects of the recent US government shutdown, so their relevance may be limited, but they paint a mixed picture. Producer prices showed a dip, while retail sales in September slipped 0.1% compared to expectations of a flat outcome.

The Case-Schiller house price index rose 1.3% month on month, to give a year on year gain of 12.8%, compared to a forecast increase of 12.5%.

Meanwhile US consumer confidence dropped to 71.2 from 80.2 in September and lower than the expected 75.

On the confidence figures James Knightley at ING said:

The Conference Board measure of US consumer confidence dropped sharply in October, presumably on the back of worries relating to the government shutdown/potential debt default and what this might have meant for growth, jobs and incomes.
Now that government is open again and debt default fears have passed we are hopeful that sentiment will recover. Unfortunately the uncertainty will have dampened growth in fourth quarter of 2013 and the clear worry is that politicians will again fail to come to an agreement in December on the budget. This means we will be faced with the very real prospect of another government shutdown in January with the US coming even closer to a debt default in February. This is not a good environment for economic activity and will make a delay of the Fed taper to late in the first quarter of 2014 or early in the second quarter of 2014 all the more likely.

With hopes that the Fed will sit on its hands for the moment, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has moved higher in early trading, up 45 points or 0.3%.

webTitle: Car industry subsidies: Abbott government fast-tracks inquiry

fields.standfirst: Productivity Commission investigation to underpin looming cabinet decision on intervention in the struggling sector
fields.body:
The Abbott government is pressing ahead with preparations for a high-stakes decision about whether to increase taxpayer support to Australia's struggling carmakers, or stick with its pre-election commitment to reduce industry support by $500m.

The government will on Wednesday outline terms of reference for a fast-tracked inquiry by the Productivity Commission to underpin a looming cabinet decision about what interventions the new Coalition government might or might not make in support of Australia's automotive manufacturers.

The inquiry will examine the structure of the industry, its work practices and profitability, and its "long-term sustainability." It will also consider "the changing international automotive environment" – including the potential for increasing exports and the "type and level of support provided to overseas manufacturers".

It will also look at the "nature of domestic demand and consumer preferences, including demand for new products and technologies" and Australia's "attractiveness as an investment location for all phases of automotive manufacturing activity".

The government is requiring interim recommendations by December 20 and a final assessment in March 2014 – ahead of the budget session in the new parliament.

Holden has been warning for some time that without more government assistance it will quit its Australian manufacturing operations.

But in unveiling the terms of reference, the government said it intended to respond to the current challenges in a "measured way". The government also pointed to "significant measures" it was already pursuing in support of the industry, including a decision not to proceed with a proposed tightening of the fringe benefits tax rules for company cars proposed by the ALP and the repeal of the carbon price.

The Productivity Commission, an independent advisory body in the treasury portfolio, traditionally takes a "dry" line on subjects like industry support – pointing out the substantial ongoing costs to the taxpayer of subsidies and other business welfare.

The treasurer, Joe Hockey, has also argued publicly that governments should not be in the business of propping up failing industries. Hockey has argued the car industry must be sustainable, and that includes pursuing a significant increase in exports.

But the industry minister, Ian Macfarlane, who is en route to Japan and China for a portfolio visit which, among other things, is expected to include a visit to Toyota, has made little secret of his support for the Australian car makers.

webTitle: BP cheers investors with $10bn asset sale and dividend hike

fields.standfirst: Despite fall in third quarter profits, the oil company's results were better than expected
fields.body:
BP has announced it will sell $10bn (£6bn) of assets in the next two years to fund returns to shareholders, as it continues to shrink in the wake of 2010's disastrous Gulf blowout.

The oil company has already sold $38bn of assets to pay for the damage caused by the accident at the Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico, which killed 11 men and became the largest environmental disaster in US history. However, the proceeds from the next $10bn sale are mostly destined for shareholders.

The announcement came as BP said its underlying replacement cost profit – its preferred profit measure, which strips out the effect of oil price fluctuations – was $3.7bn (£2.3bn) for June to September, down from $5bn for the same period last year.

BP said that production for the first nine months of 2013 was 3% higher than last year. It blamed the fall in profits on weaker refining margins, selling off refineries and reduced income from its lucrative Russian business.

In March, BP sold its half of Russian firm TNK-BP to Russian state oil firm Rosneft, bringing the curtain down on a fraught but highly profitable deal with a quartet of Russian oligarchs. In return, BP picked up more shares in Rosneft, gaining a 20% stake in the world's biggest oil producer.

In a move that pleased investors, BP announced it was increasing its dividend by 5.6% to 9.5 cents a share.

With the US district court in New Orleans expected to rule early next year on the fine BP must pay under the Clean Water Act, the company faces billions in compensation costs.

BP has already set aside $42.5bn for cleanup costs, fines and compensation related to the spill.

BP and its partners face fines of as much as $1,100 for each barrel of oil released into the Gulf if they are found negligent in their actions while drilling the well and in limiting the effects of the accident. Those fines could rise to $4,300 a barrel if the responsible parties are found to have acted with gross negligence or "wilful misconduct". The US government has told the court that about 4.9m barrels escaped into the sea; BP claims 3.26m barrels were spilt.

As the second phase of the trial ended earlier this month, Louisiana's coastal protection authority reported a surge in oil washing up on its beaches this year. More than 3m tonnes of "oily material" were cleaned up in the first eight months of this year, a 20-fold increase on last year.

webTitle: Kate Spade CEO: 'I use LinkedIn to get to know talent'

fields.standfirst: The man charged with reinventing Kate Spade talks about networking, the future of branding, and advice from Jack Welch
fields.body:
It's hard to imagine Kate Spade as a dying company, but that's what it was in 2006 when it was acquired by Liz Caliborne, Inc for $124m.

Within that same week, Liz Claiborne added someone else who was new: former Johnson & Johnson chairman William L McComb, whose job was to take two dowagers of fashion – Kate Spade and Liz Claiborne – and make them chic again.

In the seven years since McComb took charge of Liz Claiborne, the company has had more than a little surface nip and tuck. Not only did its name change to Fifth & Pacific, but McComb has been hard at work whittling down its portfolio with the focus on building out its flagship brand – Kate Spade. Most recently, the company sold off its Juicy Couture brand for $195m.

According to McComb, the decision to sell Juicy Couture, leaving Fifth & Pacific with just two brands, Lucky and Kate Spade, “is all about bringing Kate Spade to its full potential”. 

The Guardian sat down with McComb to talk about leadership activism and guiding a company such as Fifth & Pacific through the transition of rebranding.

Looking back at your career, it’s interesting that you went from a company like Johnson & Johnson to a fashion retailer such as Kate Spade. Did you have to adjust your leadership style at all when switching between the two industries?

In my case, my leadership style is what brought me here. I was a proven leader and know how to get results, and I'm marketing- and brand-driven. I have a certain brand of leadership that we call service leadership. I believe that leaders need to be present and useful to their people.

I had developed a certain leadership style, and I think that I was hired for it. There are lots of things you have to do when you change industries.

I had been in a number of different industries – consumer product, pharmaceuticals, medical devices and, in this case, fashion and retailing. Because we're now a true retailer, that in itself has an industrial profile different from that of a wholesaler of fashion goods. You have to have a certain basic set of values to change industries, including the ability to learn, the ability to listen and the ability to adapt to very different business models, and not necessarily cling to one set of truths about how companies work, even leadership models.

But leadership style, I would say is something that gets built upon, experience by experience. One thing I will say is there are remarkable similarities between companies in industries as they relate to hiring, leading, developing and motivating people. More than not, the common denominators are actually profound.

How do you keep your staff motivated?

You know, keeping my team, my staff motivated and inspired comes from keeping them very in touch with a big vision and big goals. The more viscerally people feel about that vision and their near-term and long-term goals, the more inspired and self-motivated and productive they become.

I think there's sort of two planes that you always have to work on. Everybody has, what I call, their little fire box – the thing they're working on, putting out a fire or managing a deadline, the short-term stuff. But it's also very important that – the forest for the trees analogy – they constantly re-energize [the team with] big audacious goals that involve disrupting the marketplace, taking market shares, winning over new consumers, growing. I think it's the leader's job to make sure people are connecting to that.

What did disrupting the marketplace mean for Kate Spade? Does it mean putting yourself as the company out there and experimenting with the product?

Disruption, maybe in the context that you mention it, might be an overused word, because by and large most companies have reached a certain place, and more often than not they're working to further entrench that position. So disruption may be overused and certainly it isn't in our company.

We're a company that completely reinvented and remade itself. We've swung from being a very mature and declining US wholesaler of mid-price women's fashion to being a global company with lifestyle brands across-categories, with our own direct-to-consumer channels.

The word disruption definitely applies – and I will use the case of Kate Spade, which in 2007 had a brand far bigger than its business. It was a very well known and well regarded brand that had lost cultural relevance and was managed as a very small business.

We took a step back and said we were going to allocate capital for growth directly against the consumer. We were going to take control of our brand and reimagine what Kate Spade was, with the provisional positioning that we were going to modernize it while still being classic. We were truly going to go for lifestyle branding. So what we meant by disruption is that we were literally going to disrupt the market structure and the market share. We saw brands like Coach as having an increasingly vulnerable image; they had gotten to a certain size and presence, almost ubiquitous.

So for us, disruption really was about taking a good business, with a big awareness profile, and making the business underneath that profile significant. And we've done it. What we've done is we disrupted consumer perception and market share. We're in the very early stages of it still. This is a company with a long runway for growth but disruption is the name of the game. That meant building our own capabilities in what are called the omni-channel capabilities.

One the paradigms that we disrupted is the traditional brick and mortar versus wholesale versus e-commerce component. Everybody is using the words "omni-channel" and that's a good thing. Retailers should be using it. But for us, we've reached what I'd call disruptive penetration level for Kate Spade in e-commerce. So that means disrupting behaviors, disrupting thought patterns, disrupting business models, disrupting market segments, disrupting market share, those are the contexts for disruption.

Just a few months back, you wrote an op-ed about why men should talk about domestic violence with their children. Why do you think it's important for leaders to speak on certain issues such as this one?

Well, it's so interesting. First of all, it's a responsibility you have. I mean, I sit on top of this company with more than 12,000 people and I see an awful lot of humanity and a lot of issues. The issue of domestic violence is one that our company has taken a leadership position on for longer than a decade. And we have been actually one of the three most influential companies in the United States in actually creating language and mobilizing people.

As a leader of a company that has people in far-flung regions of the world, as well as in tiny cities in American states, I have discovered painfully how the silent problems of domestic violence, beyond being a topic that we chose a long time before I got here, how it actually impacts the business environment.

And I will tell you, in my first week here, there was a murder in one of our distribution centers – where one of our best workers was murdered by her husband. And it immediately brought home the issue, it brought to life the necessity of the workplace being a safe harbor environment for people that can stand up and ask for help. The striking thing about it is, that it's a pervasive problem that strikes every socio-economic class, every age group. There are women CEOs, believe it or not, out there that have a domestic violence problem in their own house.

So for me that's the background. Add to that the fact that the world has now gotten to the place where media is very democratic, they are so many places we, as individuals, can step up. Whether it's blogging, whether it's social media, whether it's being very visible. There are so many services where we can stand up and use our voice and our position to lobby and advocate for a solution.

So, yes, I think that it's an important part of my job, of any leader's job. I think it's what leadership is about and that particular issue is very important to me.

I chose to write that op-ed as a challenge to fathers around the country to talk to their kids over Father's Day weekend. I have three sons, and it's something I've certainly included in my leadership lessons, if you want to call them that: it's what's important in being a great person and a great man.

Something that companies tend to struggle with during a transition is staying on message. How did you handle that as you are bringing in people and changing your business?

While it sounds like a really daunting task to hire people when you are in effect redressing, or reskinning, the company. I always refer to it as changing tires on the car at full speed. But while it sounds like a daunting task, it wasn't hard here, honestly.

Almost without fail, I was able to hire the people that I had identified on the outside. The reason [they came] is that we were selling a very compelling vision. People got it. I would have had a much harder time asking them to come to the old company, which was, honestly, seen as a dying business model and an aged platform – what I call a sunset situation versus sunrise situation.

When we describe how we were structured, our strategy, that we were putting all of our attention and emphasis on creating a brand franchise for consumers and lifestyle branding with global omni-channel – these are the things that some of the most talented people in the industry were flocking towards.

Effectively we were in the headlines reporting negative earnings, going through a really brutal turn in terms of the balance sheet debt, and at times going through uncertainty in terms of working capital and lines of credit. There were rumors of bankruptcy back in 2009. Honestly, people looked around and they said "You've got the right brand, you've got the right idea, some great people work there. I'm going to take the leap." And we got plenty.

It separates the strong from the weak. People who need more a comfortable situation, they were not attracted. And I was not attracted to them. I was looking for pioneers, self-starters. I was looking for people who could look me in the eye and say "Sign me up" or "I want to go to battle with you."

I think it's important, I think it's an interesting fact, it's one that I am proud of – I didn't even bring with me my administrative assistant from J&J. I didn't bring one person that I had worked with. Not one. It wasn't appropriate here. I really needed the best possible people from this industry. And so in my case, every single person I hired was an experiment. I was taking a risk I had no prior leadership experience with them. But I needed their experience in business. Without fail, that worked.

And we did make mistakes. There were times I hired somebody that would have been right in a slightly different situation. And when that happened, usually we mutually reached the same conclusion and they moved on and I would rehire. You'll never have a batting average of a thousand with hiring.

Everyone talks about networking as playing a significant role in finding the right job, or even in growing one’s company. What is your take on networking? Have you found it to be useful?

I think it's an essential element of humanity and the human condition. We network in our personal lives without even knowing we're networking. It's how humans connect. And so the answer is, networking is incredibly important personally and professionally. It works both ways.

As what I will call an "acquirer of talent", it's as important for me to have a network and be out networking as it is for people looking to be acquired. In other words, I need to be networking as much as people out in the job market looking to get hired.

I have this philosophy: "Drill a well before you need a drink." It relates to a lot of things, but particularly talent and recruiting. And so one of the first things when I got in the industry was I got out there, breakfasts, lunches and dinners, sometimes five days a week, three meals a day meeting some of the famous people in the industry, with competitors who would never come work at my company, or whom I would never be looking to hire. I met with them to to learn, to hear about their experiences, almost to know their brand, if you will, in the labor market of our industry. Invariably it led to friendships, which in turn led to references, which in turn led to connections and the people that I wanted to hire.

Today, informally, LinkedIn is an incredible network It's way for people to opt into a network and build friendships and familiarity. We use LinkedIn in a significant way and I use my own page to look at and get to know talent.

Networking is incredibly important at the peer level as well. I was very eager to meet, not only the other CEOs and founders that we compete against, but leaders of businesses that we don't compete against. These people have been able to mentor me in an informal way, and I picked up a lot of what I'd call "dirt under the fingernails" from some of these people, and over time it's been helpful. People that I in the end was able to call and say who is your distributor in Australia? – as an example. They make introductions. I would say networking is incredibly important.

Speaking of seeking out advice, what is the best business advice that you have ever gotten?

Jack Welch, at a dinner I had with him seven years ago, looked me in the eye and said, "As a CEO everyone would tell you to be careful and slow down and be cautious. But my regrets are always the decisions that I delayed or the situations that I allowed to simmer and to see if they resolved." In other words, he said my greatest regrets are the things I didn't do fast enough, not the things I did too fast. And it's the greatest advice I've had. Because, by the way, I will say seven years as the CEO here, I have the same experience. Even to this day, my greatest regrets are not that I moved to fast on anything, but that there are some things I wish I moved faster on.

webTitle: UK mortgage approvals highest since February 2008

fields.bodyText: Mortgages approved by British lenders jumped to their highest level for more than five years in September, fanning fears the housing market was already heating up even before the latest government support kicked in. Banks, building societies and other lenders approved 66,735 mortgages in September, the biggest monthly total since February 2008, before the global financial crisis took hold. The figures, from the Bank of England, were just ahead of City forecasts of 66,000 and compared with an upwardly revised 63,396 in August. Mortgage approvals are seen by economists as a good early indicator of where the housing market is headed. They follow government data on Monday showing house prices rose in every English region in September and are likely to be seized on by those who argue that the government's Help to Buy scheme risks creating a new bubble. "All the stimulus thrown at the housing market risks starting another dangerous boom-bust cycle," said Rob Wood, chief UK economist at Berenberg Bank. "The key issue is not where prices are today, rather it is where they will be in a couple of years. Prices and activity are rising fast now. We expect house prices to rise 10% year on year next year … The measures that selectively boost the housing market, like the Help to Buy scheme, should be scrapped." The plan to kickstart the property market and help homebuyers struggling to get on the property ladder gives a taxpayer-backed guarantee to lenders offering 95% mortgages that are open to first-time buyers and home movers on newbuild homes worth up to £600,000. Despite criticism from the International Monetary Fund and many economists, the scheme was expanded this month. In an attempt to quell criticism of his scheme, the chancellor, George Osborne, recently asked the Bank of England to monitor its impact and report back in a year. Howard Archer, economist at IHS Global Insight, said the latest numbers underlined the need for policymakers to be ready to act "quickly and decisively if signs of the housing market overheating become increasingly widespread and pronounced". Archer said it appeared a number of factors were supporting the property market even before the latest phase of Help to Buy was launched: improved consumer confidence, higher employment and extended low mortgage interest rates, the first stage of Help to Buy and the Funding for Lending scheme – a Bank of England initiative to increase the flow of cheap finance to credit-starved businesses. "We are currently a long way off from an overall housing market bubble emerging. Nevertheless, there is a mounting danger that house prices could really take off over the coming months, especially if already significantly improving housing market activity and rising buyer interest is lifted appreciably further by the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme," Archer added. Others argued the housing market was still well below its peak and there were few warning signs of a bubble forming. Samuel Tombs, UK economist at the thinktank Capital Economics, emphasised that mortgage lending, at £1bn, was only "a touch" above the average of £0.7bn over the previous two years. Mortgage approvals were still close to 40% down on their typical pre-recession levels, he added. "Given that interest rates on Help to Buy mortgage products look expensive and lending criteria are strict, we doubt the scheme will boost mortgage demand much. Note too that banks appear to have little appetite to substantially increase the size of their mortgage books," Tombs said. "For now, then, there remains little evidence that a renewed boom in the housing market is developing." The Bank data contained some evidence that businesses found it easier to get finance in September. After dropping sharply in August, lending to non-financial businesses rose by £720m, the biggest increase since January. "While it is important not to read too much into one month's figures, the size of the September increase in business lending reported by the Bank of England provides a significant boost to hopes that banks are now becoming more prepared to lend to businesses, given the improved economic situation and outlook," said Archer. The Bank's data showed, however, that within the overall rise, lending to small businesses fell in September. The British Chambers of Commerce said small businesses needed more help to get funds. "It's good to see overall business lending rise, as this has an impact on business confidence. Yet these new figures show that while large firms have little difficulty tapping debt markets, SMEs – and particular young, fast-growing firms – continue to struggle to access growth capital," said Adam Marshall, its director of policy and external affairs. "Both policymakers and financial institutions need to do more to help fast-growing SMEs access finance."

webTitle: Investors switch off ITV on worries about online video growth

fields.standfirst: Analysts at Berenberg move from hold to sell despite current advertising pick-up
fields.body:
ITV could lose the X-Factor, according to analysts at Berenberg.

According to the bank's analysts, the broadcaster may be doing well enough at the moment as advertising revenues pick up but it could miss out on the growing online market. So analyst Sarah Simon has moved the bank's recommendation from hold to sell with a 155p target, helping push its shares 2.8p lower to 189.1p. She said:

Our view on ITV is shaped by the conflict between its near and medium/long-term performance. While the third quarter has seen better-than- expected advertising growth, in the medium-to-long term we believe that ITV has poor online positioning and that this could be a driver of revenue downgrades over time.
We see online video starting to take share from TV budgets in the US, and expect this trend to hit the UK. In a stronger economy, marketers may embrace more risky marketing strategies, accelerating the move away from traditional media – this suggests that they could shift more quickly into online video, partly to the detriment of TV. Against this backdrop, ITV's online video performance is cause for concern, despite various management reshuffles over the last few years aimed at boosting its digital business. The company is seeing online video growth, but less than that of the overall market and key peers such as Channel 4 and the BBC. Regarding the potential for retransmission fees, we note that the near-universal availability of free-to-air terrestrial TV (not the case in the US) will make it much more difficult to charge platform operators. Moreover, if ITV was to limit distribution of the channel, this would put at risk its ability to bid for listed events such as the UEFA European Championship and the FIFA World Cup. Given our view that revenue will come under pressure in the medium term, we do not see the stock offering value, particularly as these are not "trough earnings" as is the case for other European cyclicals. We also note that while ITV has paid around 7 times earnings before interest and tax for content acquisitions, the market appears to afford a substantial premium to these assets. Given that ITV excludes the pension cost from adjusted earnings per share, its PE does not reflect the £476m liability: even without it, we think the multiple looks high. We downgrade to sell with a new price target of 155p. Catalysts include slow growth in the fourth quarter, weakening franchise shows and the Champions League rights costs.

webTitle: Housebuilders Bovis and Redrow rise after positive broker comments

fields.standfirst: Housing price boom lifts sector but Liberum plays down fears of potential bubble
fields.body:
With more and more data showing rising house prices building companies are in demand.

Much of the recent rises have been due to the government's help to buy scheme, and the situation has prompted fears that a housing market bubble is being created. But Liberum Capital has played these worries down, issuing a positive note on the sector and raising its recommendation on Bovis Homes, 20p higher at 779.5p, and Redrow, up 7.6p at 262.4p. Liberum analyst Charlie Campbell said:

We have become more positive on the housebuilders. Upgrades to Bovis (buy from hold) and Redrow (buy from hold) now mean we have five buys in the sector (out of seven).
This marks a complete reversal of the neutral stance that we adopted in May and which proved reasonably successful. We are more positive because we anticipate strong trading updates through November's mini-reporting season. But we also see house price inflation continuing without getting out of hand, and rate rise fears abating. The combination of subdued land prices and government support also make this cycle better than the last....But there are enough checks and balances to ensure that price rises do not get out of hand (subdued real incomes, more rigorous mortgage market supervision and credit checking). These positive factors should allow the sector's re-rating to continue.

Liberum also raised its price target on Persimmon, up 17p at £12.41, from £12.45 to £12.61.

webTitle: UBS forced to hold more capital amid currency probe

fields.standfirst: Swiss bank appears to admit it has taken disciplinary action against staff involved in currency markets which regulators have begun to investigate
fields.body:
Swiss bank UBS revealed on Tuesday it was co-operating with global investigations into potential manipulation of the £3tn foreign exchange market, in a stark reminder that the banking industry is still struggling to repair its reputation in the wake of the financial crisis.

It made the admission as it reported third quarter results in which it stunned the market by revealing its regulator was forcing it to hold more capital because of the risk of hefty new fines and litigation.

It said the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority was forcing it to hold more capital because of "known or unknown litigation, compliance and other operational risk matters".

The bank appeared to admit it had taken disciplinary action against staff involved in currency markets which regulators have begun to investigate. Regulators are focusing on the potential manipulation of currency benchmarks, in a move reminiscent of the Libor-rigging probe.

Bailed-out Royal Bank of Scotland is among the other major banks which have been contacted by regulators as part of the investigation, which could take months to conclude.

UBS has already paid the highest penalty – £940m – for attempting to rig Libor, the key benchmark interest rate, and has also settled claims with US regulators about the misselling of sub-prime mortgages in the run-up to the financial crisis.

A report by Bloomberg in June had raised the prospect of potential manipulation of a currency benchmark and UBS said that after that report "we immediately commenced an internal review of our foreign exchange business".

It added: "UBS and other financial institutions have received requests from various authorities relating to their foreign exchange businesses, and UBS is cooperating with the authorities.

"We have taken and will take appropriate action with respect to certain personnel as a result of our review, which is ongoing," the bank said.

It came as Deutsche Bank was forced to report a dramatic drop in third quarter profits as a result of a €1.2bn (£1bn) charge for litigation, without specifying what penalties or court cases it could be facing. Deutsche's shares fell 2.5% in early trading, with UBS down nearly 6%.

UBS is facing a setback in meeting promises on returns to shareholders as a result of being forced to hold more capital. Chief executive Sergio Ermotti, appointed in the wake of the £1.5bn Kweku Adoboli fraudulent trading scandal, tried to remain upbeat. "Our results this quarter provide more evidence that our business model works in a variety of market conditions. One year into the acceleration of our strategy we are ahead of plan on execution," Ermotti said.

He has previously announced plans to cut 10,000 jobs to try to bolster the profitability of the bank.

The Swiss regulator Finma will review the temporary add-on to the capital requirement once there is better clarity about the risks it faces from litigation and other matters, UBS said.

"Finma informed us that its decision was based on a comparison of recent loss history with the capital underpinning for operational risks," the bank said.

"Our ability to absorb this event is a prime example of the benefits of our strong capital position and our emphasis on building best-in-class capital ratios," the bank added.

Finma is among the regulators around the world to admit it is looking at the currency markets and the potential to rig a benchmark used by fund managers to set prices.

webTitle: FTSE moves higher ahead of Fed, but contrasting fortunes for BP and Lloyds

fields.standfirst: Investors remain cautious ahead of US central bank meeting with QE on the agenda
fields.body:
Leading shares are moving higher but results from key members of the oil and banking sectors have seen contrasting reactions.

BP is the biggest riser in the FTSE 100, up 22.2p at 474.3p after it raised its third quarter dividend by 5.6% and said it would sell $10bn worth of assets over the next two years and return most of the proceeds to shareholders.

The company has already disposed of $38bn worth of assets to pay for the Gulf of Mexico spill, and this helped push net profit down from $5.017bn a year ago to $3.692bn. But this was higher than consensus forecasts of around $3.17bn.

Royal Dutch Shell B shares were also better, up 21.5p at 2261.5p, following the BP news.

But Lloyds Banking Group has lost 1.71p to 77.91p after it put aside another £750m as a charge for the mis-selling of payment protection insurance, making a total of £8bn so far. Overall, Lloyds' third quarter operating profits rose by 83%. This prompted some investors to take profits after recent rises in Lloyds' shares.

Disappointing figures from UBS, Deutsche Bank and Standard Chartered - 20.5p lower at 1513.5p - also hit the sector, with Royal Bank of Scotland down 8.6p at 359.9p.

Overall though, the FTSE 100 is up 24.80 points at 6750.62, ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday. The central bank is widely expected to keep its $85bn a month bond buying programme intact for the rest of the year, but any comments on when it might begin to ease off QE will be closely watched.

Sentiment was also helped by the Peoples Bank of China injecting liquidity and easing fears of a credit crunch.

Among the mid-caps, Regus has fallen 9.7p to 195.1p after the office space supplier reported a 26% rise in third quarter revenue but said full year results would be hit by the cost of opening new centres. Peel Hunt said:

Despite tougher comparatives dampening year-on-year growth in the third quarter, management is ramping up new centre openings even faster than expected. The short-term cost to earnings is worthwhile in our view, and we increase our target price to 224p. Hold.

webTitle: Lloyds back in the red as PPI claims rise again

fields.bodyText: Lloyds Banking Group slumped to a loss in the third quarter after another £750m hit for payment protection insurance took the bailed-out bank's total bill for the mis-selling scandal to more than £8bn. The industry's total bill for PPI is now close to £20bn and Lloyds said the £8bn included £1.7bn of administrative costs. Chief executive António Horta-Osório added that discussions were under way with the industry regulator to resume dividend payments for the first time since the financial crisis. He also increased his forecasts for the bank's margins and heralded the sale of part of the government's stake last month, which produced a £60m profit. Horta-Osório said it was likely another tranche could be sold off in 2014 and that he supported the government's intention to include retail investors in the next sale. Last month, only City investors could participate in the share sale, when 15% of the tranche was sold off at 75p a share. "The hard work of the last two and half years is coming to fruition," said the Lloyds boss. He stands to receive 3m shares – worth £2.5m at current prices – if the share price can remain for 30 days in a row above the 73.6p level at which the taxpayer breaks even on its remaining 33% stake, or if a third of the stake is sold at prices over 61p. But despite his upbeat sentiment, the shares were among the biggest fallers in the FTSE 100, closing 2% lower at 78p. He promised that Lloyds would be a "high-dividend" paying stock in the future. The dividend policy will be outlined at the full-year results in February. "We are back to being a normal company," he said. Although the bank remained profitable over nine months, in the third quarter it slumped to a £440m loss because of the £750m provision for PPI and a £600m shortfall arising from losses on sales of businesses in Germany. Over the nine months, pre-tax profit was £1.7bn compared with a £607m loss in the same period last year. Horta-Osório said he supported the government Help to Buy scheme, which was leading to a significant jump in mortgage applications. He did not give details of the additional number of applications but said it was not just a London phenomenon. The bank is already providing one in four of home loans to first-time buyers, lending £6.7bn to more than 56,000 people by the end of September. Recruited from the UK arm of Spanish bank Santander to turn Lloyds around, the Portuguese banker said the exit from non-core business had been completed. The bank has pulled out of 21 countries and it is now operating in just 10 as part of its effort to be a largely domestic bank. Troublesome operations in Ireland and commercial banking were also improving, with impairment charges on bad debts falling by 9% to £1.2bn. The bank has spun out 631 branches under the TSB brand to meet EU demands y the EU that itto reduce its branch network as a result of the £20bn of state aid it received during the 2008 and 2009 bank bailouts. fields.headline: Lloyds back in the red as PPI claims rise again
fields.body:
Lloyds Banking Group slumped to a loss in the third quarter after another £750m hit for payment protection insurance took the bailed-out bank's total bill for the mis-selling scandal to more than £8bn.

The industry's total bill for PPI is now close to £20bn and Lloyds said the £8bn included £1.7bn of administrative costs.

Chief executive António Horta-Osório added that discussions were under way with the industry regulator to resume dividend payments for the first time since the financial crisis. He also increased his forecasts for the bank's margins and heralded the sale of part of the government's stake last month, which produced a £60m profit.

Horta-Osório said it was likely another tranche could be sold off in 2014 and that he supported the government's intention to include retail investors in the next sale. Last month, only City investors could participate in the share sale, when 15% of the tranche was sold off at 75p a share.

"The hard work of the last two and half years is coming to fruition," said the Lloyds boss. He stands to receive 3m shares – worth £2.5m at current prices – if the share price can remain for 30 days in a row above the 73.6p level at which the taxpayer breaks even on its remaining 33% stake, or if a third of the stake is sold at prices over 61p.

But despite his upbeat sentiment, the shares were among the biggest fallers in the FTSE 100, closing 2% lower at 78p. He promised that Lloyds would be a "high-dividend" paying stock in the future. The dividend policy will be outlined at the full-year results in February. "We are back to being a normal company," he said.

Although the bank remained profitable over nine months, in the third quarter it slumped to a £440m loss because of the £750m provision for PPI and a £600m shortfall arising from losses on sales of businesses in Germany. webTitle: Energy firms raised prices despite drop in wholesale costs

fields.bodyText: Some of Britain's big six energy companies have seen their wholesale electricity costs fall over the last three years while still putting up prices for millions of households. The figures will put yet more pressure on the firms to explain why bills and UK profits have been going up, as they appear before a influential House of Commons committee of MPs. According to Ofgem, Npower paid an average of £59.61 per megawatt-hour for electricity in 2010. The average wholesale price fell by 4% to £57.32 in 2011 and rose by less than 2% to £58.39 in 2012. The company increased retail prices by 5.1%, 7.2% and 9.1% respectively in those years. Similarly, EDF paid wholesale prices for electricity supplied to households of £58.16MWh in 2010, falling by 0.6% to £57.82 in 2011 and rising less than 5% to £60.68 in 2012. In those years EDF's electricity prices to customers went up by 7.5%, 4.5% and 10.8% respectively. Meanwhile E.ON paid £57.64MWh for its electricity in 2010, rising by 7% to £61.82 in 2011 and falling by 4% to £59.44 in 2012. It raised its power prices twice by a cumulative 20% in 2011, before cutting them by 6% in 2012. Asked why wholesale prices appeared to be out of kilter with increases in bills, companies said network and environmental costs had been the biggest factor in higher electricity bills, which are now around £600 a year on average. However, figures from Ofgem indicate electricity network costs have only risen by £10 in each of the last four years, while green costs are rising by a similar amount. Green and social levies make up £112, or less than 9%, of the average household energy bill. With four of the big six – British Gas, Npower, Scottish Power and SSE – announcing big price rises in the last few weeks, the companies are under increasing pressure to justify the increases, after figures from the energy regulator suggested the profit margin made by the companies per household has more than doubled from £45 to £95 over the last year. Ofgem said wholesale energy costs have gone up by just £10 in a year, while VAT, operating and other costs are up £40. The energy companies dispute this analysis and point to higher wholesale costs this winter. Downing Street yesterday said energy companies should account for the latest round of price rises, which have averaged 9% this autumn. Energy bill increases are continuing to cause a headache for the coalition, as a new YouGov poll shows 68% of the public believes Labour's energy price feeze is workable. Caroline Flint, shadow energy secretary, called on the companies to "come clean about why they are imposing yet another round of inflation-busting price rises this winter, when they are already making huge profits". "Revelations about rising profits and the growing gap between wholesale costs and household energy bills highlight why answers are needed," she said. Which?, the consumer group, yesterday called on the chancellor to tackle rising bills. The group said it wants the companies broken up and an end to the "blank cheque" of allowing energy companies to charge customers whatever they like for a government scheme to cut energy usage for poorer households. Will Straw, associate director at of the IPPR thinktank, also questioned why the big six think "profits of 5% to 6% are acceptable in a competitive market". "In 1998, as the market was liberalised, the regulator believed 1.5% was an adequate margin for energy suppliers. Profits in other sectors like supermarkets are as low as 2%." Asked about the wholesale power prices, a spokesman for nPower pointed to comments by Paul Massara, its chief executive, who said earlier this year: "The main factor behind rising costs is government policy and regulation to fund this country's transition to a more efficient economy, with modern infrastructure and warm, insulated homes for all." An EDF spokesman said wholesale energy costs have "not been the main driver of increases in prices". He added: "When we last raised our prices in December 2012 we made it clear that a major driver was the increases we were seeing in the charges for transmission and distribution of energy to our customers." He also said EDF made no profit from supplying residential homes in the last three years and said it was impossible to do a "perfect match-back between the tariff increases and the year-on-year increase in costs". A spokesman for E.ON acknowledged wholesale prices influenced its power prices but said "energy bills are about much more than just wholesale costs", with just over 2% accounting for profit. In the House of Lords last night, Lord Jenkin condemned the energy "oligopoly" and tabled an amendment calling for greater competition. Another amendment in favour of decarbonising all of Britain's electricity by 2030, tabled by Lord Oxburgh, a former chairman of Shell, narrowly failed to pass.
